HL7 Standard.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide primarily focuses on defining and sharing eCQMs using FHIR resources and CQL. It heavily relies on FHIR and incorporates elements of cross-paradigm thinking by integrating CQL. It does not utilize CDA, v2, or v3.

Geographic Scope.summary: The Implementation Guide explicitly states its primary scope is within the US Realm, focusing on standardized representation of electronic Clinical Quality Measures (eCQMs). It mentions relevance to US jurisdictions and programs, such as CMS quality reporting programs. While acknowledging broader applicability, the focus remains on US-specific needs.

Domain Focus.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide primarily focuses on the standardized representation and sharing of electronic Clinical Quality Measures (eCQMs). It leverages FHIR, CQL, and QI-Core to define computable quality measures, enabling automation and data exchange for quality reporting and improvement. While it touches upon clinical data and workflow aspects related to measure evaluation, its core purpose is centered around defining and structuring quality measures themselves.

Implementers.summary: This IG focuses on the standardized representation of eCQMs using FHIR, CQL, and QI-Core. It primarily targets systems involved in authoring, distributing, and evaluating quality measures. EHRs will need to support measure evaluation and reporting, while Clinical Decision Support systems will leverage these measures for providing guidance. Payer and Public Health systems may utilize these measures for quality reporting and population health management, respectively. Research platforms can use this IG for defining and evaluating measures in research studies.

Users & Stakeholders.summary: This FHIR Implementation Guide (IG) primarily targets developers and implementers of quality measures, with a strong emphasis on enabling consistent, computable, and shareable definitions. Clinical care teams and public health agencies have a defined but limited role, while patients, caregivers, and payers are not meaningfully involved.
